areaDesc.2: Level to rolling. Principal subdivisions known as Burtonville and Earl Place.
areaDesc.3: Good schools, churches, bus line. All utilities in and majority of streets paved.
areaDesc.4: Low land at Early Place and Hull Steet which does not drain properly after very heavy rains.
areaDesc.14: Two-story frame houses about 25 years old predominate in portion of this area from Finley Avenue to Cramer Avenue and from Norman Bridge Road to Hull Street.

15.1: B. Frank Noble, Montgomery District Appraiser, and checked by Norman W. Gayle, State Appraiser, Alabama H. O. L. C.

areaDesc.2: Slightly rolling; not wooded; known as Ridgecrest. Land is prairie soil.
areaDesc.4: About 3 miles from City, with no bus facilities (taxies make special rate). Unpaved streets; no sidewalks; long distance to schools and business center, necessitating ownership of automobiles.

5.a: Mixed, including clerical workers and small business proprietors.

areaDesc.14: If proposed negro development fostered by Catholic Church materializes, future trend of residential desirability will be downward. Development of this section began in 1925 by auction sale of lots, consequently many of the purchasers were speculators with the result that many of the lots eventually were returned to the developers. Present owners of subdivision now own at least 50% of the unimproved property.

15.1: B. Frank Noble, District Appraiser, and checked by Norman W. Gayle, State Appraiser, Alabama H. O. L. C.

areaDesc.2: Slightly low; level to rolling; known as Edgewood-Thomas and new un-named subdivision.
areaDesc.3: Adjoining high class residential section which is 75% built-up. all public utilities in except gas. Close to college and 2 country clubs. Zoned and restricted as to price of residence. Pleasant topography and nice surroundings.
areaDesc.14: Edgewood-Thomas subdivision in this area is about 2 years old with best lots selling for about $20 per front foot, while remaining subdivision has just recently been plated and lot of prices have not been announced.

15.1: B. Frank Noble, Montgomery District Appraiser

areaDesc.2: Majority slightly rolling; sparsely wooded. Land in this area is prairie land, which fact must be taken into consideration when building new houses. Principal subdivisions in the area are Cloverdale, Sellers, Thomas, and Allendale.
areaDesc.3: Majority of streets paved and utilities such as water, gas, electricity, and telephones installed. Area zoned for apartments and residences only; restricted to whtie occupancy. 1 school, 2 churches, 3 parks, 2 business centers, good bus transportation facilities operating on 15 minute schedule, adjoins 2 private gold courses, pleasant topography and nice surroundings.
areaDesc.4: Paving assessments along Lexington Road still have three years to run.
areaDesc.13: Stable, but older portion will show downward trend within next few years.
areaDesc.14: (1) 50% of houses in this area are of the predominating type; remainder are mixed types. (2) Influx of Maxwell Field Officers and families created strong demand with resultant excessive rentals during depth of depression. (3) Houses built for home owners, hence not for sale. Many of Cloverdale houses not worth exhorbitant asking sale prices, but location of the section stabilizes values (both sales and rentals). This area contains 7 apartment houses containing about 90 units.

15.1: B.F. Noble, Montgomery District Appraiser and checked by N.W. Gayle, State Appraiser, Alabama H. O. L. C.

areaDesc.2: Majority slightly rolling; not wooded. Principal subdivision is South Cloverdale.
areaDesc.3: All utilities in, zoned for apartments and residences only, restricted to white occupancy. Near 1 school, 2 churches, 3 parks, 2 business centers, good bus transportation facilities, pleasant topography and nice surroundings.
areaDesc.4: Only 1 street paved in area, others gravel. Paving assessments on Montezuma Road have three years still to run.

5.a: Business men, professional men, clerical workers,

11.a: Mixed 1 sty brick and frame duplexes

15.1: H.A. Yarbrough, Montgomery District Fee Appraiser; B. F. Noble, Montgomery District Appraiser. Checked by N. W. Goyle, State Appraiser, Alabama H. O. L. C.

areaDesc.2: Practically level; not wooded. Principal subdivisions known as College Court and Watson's subdivision.
areaDesc.3: 3 blocks from school, good bus transportation facilities, zoned and restricted for apartments and residences, all public utilities in, adjacent to Huntington College and private golf course.
areaDesc.4: Small encroachment of negro property affects portion of eastern side of this area; these occupants will eventually leave the area.

5.a: Mixed; executives, professional men and clerical workers.

areaDesc.14: This is small, well developed section and contains apartment houses wtih 26 units.

15.1: B. F. Noble, Montgomery District Appraiser and checked by N. W. Gayle, State Appraiser, Alabama H. O. L. C.

areaDesc.2: Elevated but level; not wooded; contains subdivisions known as Hubbard's and Clitheral.
areaDesc.3: Close to better elementary schools (Bellinger Hill School) and churches; all utilities in all streets paved.

5.a: Mixed, ranging from retired capitalists to clerical workers.

areaDesc.13: Stable, with declining tendency in northern portion.
areaDesc.14: 60% of houses in this area are 1 story, 6 room singles while remainder are 2 story singles. Southern boundary of this area contains high class residences occupied by well-to-do citizens (along Felder Avenue).

15.1: B. F. Noble, Montgomery District Appraiser; checked by N. W. Gayles, State Appraiser, Alabama H. O. L. C.

areaDesc.2: Majority low and level; not wooded. Principal subdivisions known as Oakley's and Bailey's subdivisions.
areaDesc.3: Good school building. Public utilities all in. Good bus transportation facilities. Within walking distance of City. Area has neighborhood business community.
areaDesc.4: Majority of streets unpaved. Court Street in business section of this area at Elizabeth Street is subject to overflow after continued heavy rains, due to uncovered drainage ditch (Genetta Ditch), but proposed Federal project will alleviate this condition.
areaDesc.14: Property along Court Street side of this area is of much better grade than that in remainder of area.

15.1: B. Frank Noble, Montgomery District Appraiser, H. O. L. C.

areaDesc.2: Mostly level; not wooded. Principal subdivisions known as Sayre-Holcombe, Tharp, Peacock, Homeview, Irmadale. Some low land along Genetta Ditch.
areaDesc.3: All utilities except gas, which is available in certain sections of the area, and city water, which, although available, is not installed in small portions of the area. Two parks, churches, schools.
areaDesc.4: Majority of streets not paved; fair transportation facilities; no residential restrictions, certain sections zoned for business. In certain portions of area surface toilets necessitate use of scavenger service. Small amount of business encroachment. Genetta Ditch traverses small portion of area and is subject to overflow. Houses of advanced age of show dilapidation. Portions subject vandalism.

5.a: Skilled mechanics, domestics, clerical workers, and laborers

areaDesc.13: Stable for negro desirability. Declining steadily for whites
areaDesc.14: This is the largest negro area in the City; wage-earners work in homes, fertilizer factories, railroad shops. Houses in western and northern portion of this area are in much poorer repair than remainder of area.

15.1: B. Frank Noble, Montgomery District Appraiser, James M. Holt, Montgomery Property Management Contract Broker, and Theo D. Copeland, Montgomery Property Management Field Inspector.

areaDesc.2: Slightly rolling. Contains subdivisions known as Baby Farms (adjacent to South Cloverdale), Greil's Abraham's, and Ball's; remainder undeveloped - principally dairies. Only about 25 houses in the entire area.
areaDesc.3: Proximity to high-grade residential districts and $1,00,000 new high school. Water and electricity already installed.
areaDesc.4: No utilities other than lights and water. No sewerage.

5.a: Mixed; ranging from negro farmers to business executives.

6.b: Ranges from 1-story frame to 2-story Colonial brick

areaDesc.14: Majority of property in this area is owned by estates; development has hence been retarded, thus throwing new growth southeasterward. East and west sides of Cleveland Avenue within this area are improved with about 10 high-class residences of estate type, ranging in price from $7,500 upward. These properties are owner-occupied and are not for sale. The red spot (southeast corner of Fairview Avenue and Goode Street) comprises 4 blocks of improved property occupied principally by negroes; the buildings in this red spot are in poor condition and will undoubtedly be demolished if the area is eventually developed into high-class residential subdivisions.

15.1: B. Frank Noble, Montgomery District Appraiser

areaDesc.2: Elevated and rolling. Principal subdivisions known as New Philadelphia, East Alabama, Cramer, and Whitman.
areaDesc.3: Good schools, churches, proximity to center of City, a few parks; all utilities in; majority of streets paved.
areaDesc.4: Absence of restrictions but zoned; heavy traffic in some sections; infiltration of lower grade population; encroachments by business, industrial, and apartments. Increase in number of boarding and rooming houses. Advanced age of improvements.

5.a: Mixed; clerical workers, skilled mechanixs, along with some of City's oldest and bext families

areaDesc.14: Land in the area which adjoins business section is experiencing upward trend in value for commercial purposes. (1) Many of the large 2-story frame singles in this area were adaptable for "doubling-up" purposes, hence enjoyed good rental income during depth of depression and many have since been converted into housekeeping apartments. Eight apartments in this area contain about 80units.

15.1: B. Frank Noble, Montgomery District Appraiser, H. O. L. C.

areaDesc.2: Rolling and low; known as Goldthwaite, and East Alabama.
areaDesc.3: Churches and schools; all utilities in.
areaDesc.4: Absences of restrictions but portions zoned for business purposes, heavy traffic on High Street. Business encroachment. Moderate amount vandalism. City garbage disposal plant located near extreme eastern boundary of area.
areaDesc.14: Wage-earners in this area are within walking distance of sources of employment.

15.1: B. Frank Noble, Montgomery District Appraiser, H. O. L. C.

areaDesc.2: Mostly level with some low land; sparsely wooded. Principal subdivisions known as Highland Park, Highland Park South, the Uplands, and Primrose Heights although entire area is generally known as Oak Park.
areaDesc.3: Proximity to large public park (Oak Park), good schools, chruches. Neighborhood stores. All utilities in; only major streets paved.
areaDesc.4: Bus lines run only along boundaries of the area. Main line of Central of Georgia R. R. traverses area and as a consequence lumber yards, coal yards are located along the railroad in the central portion of the area, while gasoline storage tanks are located in extreme southeastern section of area, Hubbard Hospital located opposite Oak Park. Jerry building in eastern portion. Remote eastern portion experiencing infiltration of lower income group.
areaDesc.14: This area contains one of the oldest outlying residential sections in Montgomery and hence has a mixed type of construction, although 1-story singles predominate. Most of the occupants of the area work in the city, have 2 miles to go to work (15 minutes buse schedule - 5 cent rate).

15.1: B. Frank Noble, Montgomery District Apraiser, H. O. L. C.

areaDesc.2: Majority level; not wooded; known as Irwin Place.
areaDesc.3: Good school facilities; all public utilities in.
areaDesc.4: No streets paved, only fair transportaion facilities (about 2 miles from City); absence of restrictions. Ravine traverses northeaestern section with resultant soil erosion affecting about one sixth of this area.

5.a: Clerical, skilled mechanics, wage earners, laborers

15.1: B. Frank Noble, Montgomery District Appraiser, H. O. L. C.

areaDesc.2: This area contains highest land in Montgomery, although level; not wooded. All known as Capitol Heights.Type of soil very good for construction purposes - much better than Cloverdale.
areaDesc.3: Good schools, churches, recreational parks; good transportation facilities; restricted against stores, zoned for apartments and residences; all utilities in and most of the streets paved.
areaDesc.4: Tuberculosis sanotarium is located about one half mile distant; special assessments along Winona Street have about 3 years still to run. In extreme northeastern portion of area, an infiltration of lower income population is occurring, and this particular portion of the area is slightly lower land than remainder of the area. City garbage disposalm plant located near extreme western boundary of this area.
areaDesc.14: There are about 6 apartment houses in this area containing some 35 units; 5 of thse apartments were foreclosed, but are not fully occupied.

15.1: B. Frank Noble, Montgomery District Appraiser and checked by Norman W. Gayle, State Appraiser, Alaba,a H. O. L. C.

areaDesc.2: Rolling to level; sparsely wooded. Subdivisions knwon as Goldthwaite, Highland Park South, and Weil's Addition.
areaDesc.3: Negro schools, churches, hospital, business centers, State Teachers College, Federal Slum Clearance low-cost housing project built at cost of about $450,000 (completed 6 months ago and still unoccupied). All utilities in or available.
areaDesc.4: Genetta Ditch traverses area and is subject to occasional overflow. Fifty per cent of this area utilizes surface toilets, necessitating scavenger service. Vandalism present.

5.a: Mixed; domestics, clerical workers, laborers, and colored faculty members.

areaDesc.13: Stable for negro residential desirability, but streadily downward for whites.
areaDesc.14: This area contains largest concentration of better grade engro citizens due principally to location of negro college within the area, although at the same time, the area also contains a clum type of property. (1) Higher incomes attributed to negro college professors, doctors, and mail carriers.

15.1: B. Frank Noble, Montgomery District Appraiser.

areaDesc.3: Business center along Bell Street; location of railraod shops and factories in the area. Proximity to Maxwell Field ($12,000,000) investment) and $500,000 white slum clearance project to house some 120 families (ready for occupancy for past 90 days).
areaDesc.4: No paved streets; limited sewers and gas. Absence of residential zoning or restrictions. Garbage dump located in area; also fertilizer plant. Advanced agae of properties and poor state of repair of same. Vandalism present.
areaDesc.14: Recognized as very poor mill section, developed about 40 years ago and tenanted by low white income group. This area vitally affected by operations of 2 textile mills within the area. (1) Practically no demand for property in this area, hence no authentic sales record. (2) This section contains highest rental delinquency, both at high and low as well as at present time.

15.1: B. Frank Noble, Montgomery District Appraiser, and Theo D. Copeland, Montgomery Property Management Field Inspector.

areaDesc.2: Mostly low and level; sparsely wooded. Subdivisions known as North Montgomery, Vesuvious, Montgomery Land and Imrpovement Company.
areaDesc.3: Proximity to occopants employment, such as railroads, manufacturing plants, fertilizer plants, packing and slaughter houses, cotton compresses, lumper yards,
areaDesc.4: Majority of streets unpaved; about 10% of the area subject to overflow by Alabama River after prolonged rains. Vandalism present with tendency to be extreme in outlying portions. Only fair transportation facilities. Absences of zoning and residential restrictions in all except extreme southern portion, which is also only section having sufficient utilities; remainder of area dependent upon scavenger service. Obnoxious odors from fertilizer plants and slaughter houses. Gasoline storage tanks located in the area.
areaDesc.13: For negro home ownership poor; for negro tenancy good; for whites, steadily downward.
areaDesc.14: More complete utilities in southern portion of this area. Very high rental delinquency in this area, both whites and negroes. No recovery of sales prices in this area, due to lack of demand even for investment purpsoes.

15.1: B. Frank Noble, Montgomery District Appraiser.

areaDesc.3: Adjacent to good school, small neighborhood business center; cheap cost of land. Location of automobile tire fabric plant in area provides employment for occupants of area.
areaDesc.4: Lack of public utilities (no gas or sewers); Inadequate transportation facilities (present agitation for 8 cent rate beyond City limits); absence of restrictions and zoning; proximity to Tuberculosis Sanitarium, slaughter houses, and fertilizer plants. No paved streets or sidewalks. Limited fire protection in Chishol, (75% value clause applies to fire insurance).

g.1: slowly in Highland Gardens; Chisholm - static.

5.a: Skilled mechanics, farmers, clerical workers, factory workers, and laborers

areaDesc.13: Stable for present type of resident
areaDesc.14: This area contains most fertile farming land near Montgomery. Chisholm is an old section, while Highland Gardens is newer and contains a cheaper type of property consisting principally of smaller units.

15.1: B. Frank Noble, Montgomery District Appraiser, and Theo D. Copeland, Montgomery Property Management Field inspector.
